newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Ecofin failS to agree EMU stability pact.
newsitem.headline: Ecofin failS to agree EMU stability pact.

text.p: The ECOFIN Council failed to agree on Monday on a pact to ensure countries keep their budgets stable after the 1999 start of economic and monetary union (EMU), German finance state secretary Juergen Stark said.

In the meeting, Germany held out for a strict "stability pact", standing by its original proposals for heavy sanctions against countries that allow their budget deficits to exceed three percent of gross domestic product (GDP).
Unlike other prospective EMU participants, it also wants a numerical definition of a recession severe enough to allow countries to avoid such sanctions.
Stark, who took German Finance Minister Theo Waigel's place at the meeting, said the content of the hoped-for consensus was more important than reaching agreement by a specific deadline.
"Sanctions are an important, a necessary element for us," Stark told journalists at a briefing.

"In the end we will present a credible stability pact to the public. I am optimistic we will be able to quantify the definitions. If the Commission is not yet ready to reach consensus, that means we need more time."
The EU has been hoping to agree a post-EMU stability pact by the summit of EU leaders in Dublin on December 13 and 14.

Most European countries have agreed on a formula that would fine countries 0.2 percent of GDP if their deficit exceeds three percent of GDP, and a further 0.1 percent for each percentage point up to a maximum fine of 0.5 percent of GDP.
But Germany seeks higher monetary sanctions starting at 0.25 percent of GDP, with no cap, Stark said.

Germany also hopes to the pact will define a severe recession as one that lasts for four consecutive quarters or more, or one in which a country's economic output declines by two percent or more in a single year.
Other countries are hoping to avoid numerical definitions, he said.
Two weeks ago, Stark threatened that Germany would pull out of the EMU process if the stability pact is watered down.
